intro: Muscari deserticola, commonly known as the desert squill, is a bulbous plant native to arid regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllis family (Amaryllidaceae) and is characterized by its dense clusters of small, bell-shaped blue or violet flowers. The plant produces a basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves and has a short, stout stem that bears the inflorescence. It is adapted to survive in dry conditions, with a dormant period during the hot summer months. Muscari deserticola is often used in rock gardens and xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance and ornamental value.
